blocks.section: Intensive Care Nursery House Staff Manual

blocks.preview: INTRODUCTION: Many sick newborn infants cannot obtain adequate nutrition via the GI tract and, thus,
- Sick newborns usually have increased caloric requirements.
- Minimal caloric requirements to prevent catabolism are at least $40 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{kg} /
- For growth, minimal requirements are $80 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ and protein int
- Nutrition support should be initiated within 3 days of birth and should include protein. A "starte
- Start PN when at least $30 \mathrm{cc} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ can be used for this route.
- Although growth can be obtained with PN, enteral feedings should be initiated as soon as feasible,
1. Peripheral route is used for partial or supplemental PN. This route is usually used for short-ter
2. Central PN is delivered by a venous catheter with the tip in a central location (see the section
Neonatal nutrition support literature supports early and aggressive nutrition support for the VLBW i
birth with higher initial amounts is well tolerated. "Starter TPN" is now available on the unit to d
1. Target infants are $<1200$ grams or $<30$ weeks or those expected to require parental support bas
2. 150 ml bags of D10AA3.5, no electrolytes are stocked in the ICN East refrigerator.
3. The admitting MD/NNP writes the admit orders to initiate "starter" TPN as one of the IVF at $60-8
4. Maximum "starter" TPN amount is $100 \mathrm{ml} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day. Additional IVF will be ord
5. For fluid restriction, the "starter" TPN can run at a lower rate but the protein intake will be l
6. The admitting MD/NNP will also write the TPN order for the next bag, advancing as per ICN guideli
COMPONENTS OF PARENTERAL NUTRITION include:
1. Protein is administered as a solution of amino acids, Premasol ${ }^{\mathrm{TM}}$, a preparation
- Start amino acids at $2-3 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$, as much as possible depending o
- Maximum is $3 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ in term infants and $3.5 \mathrm{~g} / \math
- Include protein in you calorie count. Protein yields $4 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{g}$.
Potential complications/risk include:
- Acidosis
- Elevated BUN
- Hyperammonemia
- Cholestasis with prolonged administration
2. Carbohydrate is administered as dextrose monohydrate.
- Start with $4-6 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{min}$ or D10-D12.5. Alternatively, calculate t
- Very preterm infants may not tolerate that much dextrose and may even need insulin as an infusion
- Advance by $1-3 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{min}$ daily to a maximum of $12 \mathrm{mg} /
- Dextrose yields $3.4 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{g}$.
- Consult reverse side of TPN order sheet for maximal allowable dextrose/amino acid concentrations.
- Potential complications/risks include:
- Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
- Glycosuria and potential osmotic diuresis
- Cholestasis and/or hepatic steatosis with high caloric intake usually from long-term high concentr
3. Fat: Intravenous lipid emulsions are essential components of TPN. They provide essential fatty ac
- A lipid intake of $0.25-0.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ is required to prevent essenti
- Include lipid emulsion in calculations of total fluid intake.
- Lipids yield $10 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{g}$.
- IV lipid preparations are available as a $20 \%$ soybean emulsion that yields 2 $\mathrm{kcal} / \
- See Table below for starting and advancing lipids.
- Deliver IV lipids over 24 hours.
- Do not allow lipids to exceed $60 \%$ of total caloric intake.
- Potential complications/risks include:
- Hyperlipidemia
- Potential risk of kernicterus at low levels of unconjugated bilirubin because of displacement of b
- Potential increased risk or exacerbation of chronic lung disease
- Potential exacerbation of Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension (PPHN)
- Lipid overload syndrome with coagulopathy and liver failure
Table 1. Guidelines for starting and increasing IV lipid emulsions by clinical status.

5. Minerals: Preterm infants and term infants receiving long-term parenteral nutrition are at increa

- Follow ionized calcium and weekly pediatric TPN panels.
- Do not start magnesium until the serum level is $<2.5 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}$.

6. Other Additives include:
- Trace elements are recommended as $0.2 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ of trace element s
- Preterm infants need additional zinc $(300 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d})$ and selenium
- Term infants need additional zinc $(200 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d})$ and selenium ( 2
- For infants with cholestasis (i.e,. direct bilirubin $>2.5 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}$ ), discontin
- Zinc $400 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ TOTAL (preterm infants)
- $300 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$ TOTAL (term infants)
- Chromium $0.2 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$
- Selenium $2 \mathrm{mcg} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{d}$
- Discontinue selenium with patients on renal dialysis.
- $\cdot$Vitamins: Pediatric multivitamins are recommended as $2.0 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} / \mat
- $\cdot$Heparin ( $1 \mathrm{unit} / \mathrm{mL}$ ) is added to all central venous lines and to all
